abstract.p: High-CO 2 induced ocean acidification (OA) reduces the calcium carbonate (CaCO 3) saturation level (Ω) and the pH of oceans. Consequently, OA is causing a serious threat to several ecologically and economically important biomineralising molluscs. Biomineralisation is a highly controlled biochemical process by which molluscs deposit their calcareous structures. In this process, shell matrix proteins aid the nucleation, growth and assemblage of the CaCO 3 crystals in the shell. These molluscan shell proteins (MSPs) are, ultimately, responsible for determination of the diverse shell microstructures and mechanical strength. Recent studies have attempted to integrate gene and protein expression data of MSPs with shell structure and mechanical properties. These advances made in understanding the molecular mechanism of biomineralisation suggest that molluscs either succumb or adapt to OA stress. In this review, we discuss the fate of biomineralisation process in future high-CO 2 oceans and its ultimate impact on the mineralised shell's structure and mechanical properties from the perspectives of limited substrate availability theory, proton flux limitation model and the omega myth theory. Furthermore, studying the interplay of energy availability and differential gene expression is an essential first step towards understanding adaptation of molluscan biomineralisation to OA, because if there is a need to change gene expression under stressors, any living system would require more energy than usual. To conclude, we have listed, four important future research directions for molecular adaptation of molluscan biomineralisation in high-CO 2 oceans: 1) Including an energy budgeting factor while understanding differential gene expression of MSPs and ion transporters under OA. 2) Unraveling the genetic or epigenetic changes related to biomineralisation under stressors to help solving a bigger picture about future evolution of molluscs, and 3) Understanding Post Translational Modifications of MSPs with and without stressors. 4) Understanding carbon uptake mechanisms across taxa with and without OA to clarify the OA theories on Ω.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Biomineralisation in molluscs is an actively controlled, biochemical process by which calcareous (calcium carbonate -CaCO 3 ) structures are formed by amalgamating calcium and carbonate ions along with proteins, carbohydrates and lipids. Molluscs are the oldest extant biomineralising bilaterians (Knoll, 2003). One of the major quoted examples of biomineralisation in the oceans is a molluscan shell. The origin of molluscan shells traces back to the Cambrian explosion, 540 million years ago approximately (Marin et al., 2012), when the living organisms in our planet exploded into diversity. The soft bodied marine molluscs acquiring the biomineralising ability during Cambrian explosion, marks a significant milestone in the history of evolution of our planet. Though there are several other types of mineralised structures such as spicules, shells are known for their abundance, protective and evolutionary role (Meldrum, 2003). The shells not only serve as a receptacle for the soft body but also protects it from predators and other environmental stressors. Phylum mollusca contains diverse range of species which forms calcareous shells. Many of these species are important ecologically (filter feeders, reef formers (oyster reefs), habitat formers etc.) and economically as food resources for humans and many other marine species. However, most abundant information on molluscan biomineralisation is on bivalves (Dauphin and Cuif, 2018) and hence the major example quoted in this review would be bivalves. Pinctada species is the widely studied because of the commercial interest over "pearl formation" (Suzuki and Nagasawa, 2013). After bivalves, gastropods are the next to be extensively studied for understanding biomineralisation (Suzuki and Nagasawa, 2013).

As shown in Fig. 1, molluscan shells are primarily made of calcium carbonate (CaCO 3 ) crystal units with 1-5% organic content (Zaremba et al., 1996). The organic content mainly composed of matrix proteins, polysaccharides (e.g. chitin) and pigments (Marin et al., 2012;Zentz et al., 2001;Hedegaard et al., 2006). Matrix proteins occluded in these biologically assembled crystals provide shells with incredible mechanical properties. For example: nacre microstructure is 3000 times more resistant to fracture than a pure single aragonite crystal (Currey, 1977). Molluscan shell matrix proteins (MSPs) are found to initiate nucleation and aid in the controlled formation of CaCO 3 crystals (Yan et al., 2007). MSPs are expressed and secreted by mantle tissue (Ivanina et al., 2017) and are pervaded in the tightly packed molluscan shell microstructures (Chateigner et al., 2000). Therefore, identification and quantification of MSPs have been recognised as one of the key steps towards understanding biomineralisation (Michenfelder et al., 2003). Several MSPs have been now characterised (Miyamoto et al., 1996;Marie et al, 2012aMarie et al, , 2012bSuzuki et al., 2004), especially in pearl oysters due to the huge commercial interest in pearl formation. In general, MSPs are heavily glycosylated or phosphorylated, with a net negative charge (Weiner and Hood, 1975;Marin et al, 2000;Marxen et al., 2003). Signature ionic interactions of these proteins with the mineral phase are found to be responsible for the formation of unique shell microstructures (Weiner and Hood, 1975;Pendola and Evans, 2018).

There are two general types of CaCO 3 crystal polymorphs found in molluscan shellscalcite, aragonite and a rare polymorph vaterite (Marin et al., 2012;Spann et al., 2010). The percentage of aragonite and calcite in molluscan shells varies with life stages of a species and also across taxa (Stenzel, 1963;Falini et al., 1996). For example, molluscan larval shells predominantly contain aragonite with amorphous calcium carbonate as a precursor when compared to their adult counterparts (Weiss et al., 2002). The type of shell crystal polymorph is also controlled by the MSPs that are polyanionic. The raw material for molluscan biomineralisation, i.e. calcium and bi-carbonate ions, is primarily derived from the sea water and food. Though the exact mechanism of transport of these ions remains an open question (Khalifa et al., 2018), it is widely accepted that the CaCO 3 saturation state (Ω) of the sea water is one of the important parameters that determine the rate of biomineralisation process (Orr et al., 2005).

Saturation level of both calcite and aragonite minerals (Ω cal and Ω arg ) are now experiencing a rapidly decreasing trend in global oceans and it has also started fluctuating at an unprecedented higher magnitude in coastal oceans due to the absorption of excessive human CO 2 (Yamamoto-Kawai et al., 2009;Raven et al., 2005). This human induced process of ocean carbonate chemistry change is popularly called as ocean acidification (OA) (Orr et al., 2005;Kroeker et al., 2010). Decreasing saturation state of CaCO 3 minerals under OA is causing a threat for biomineralisation, not only in molluscs (Caldeira and Wickett, 2005) but also for several other calcifying marine organisms (Orr et al., 2005). Reduction in internal pH at the calcification site and ability to uptake dissolved inorganic carbon is also affected under OA (Lu et al., 2018;Venn et al., 2013). Thus, OA forces organisms to use additional energy to maintain an internal pH homeostasis/acid-base regulation, which severely impairs or alters biomineralisation process and the energy budget (Pan et al., 2015;Vidal-Dupiol et al., 2013;Hüning et al., 2013). Energetically expensive metamorphosis, a transition process that transforms pelagic larvae to benthic juveniles also increases their vulnerability to OA (Li et al., 2014). Simultaneously, the larvae must switch their shell composition from "aragonite" to "calcite" (Stenzel, 1963(Stenzel, , 1964. Also, aragonite larval shells are 50% more soluble than calcite (Gazeau et al., 2010), which makes larval stages highly vulnerable in future oceans. The direction and magnitude of the OA effect on these two key processesion homeostasis and metamorphosis, however, depend on the species, population, length of exposure and generation time, availability of genetic variability in a population, and importantly, physiological limits and short-term adaptability of a population (Kroeker et al., 2010;Campanati et al., 2018).

In this article, we discuss the pressing questions in this field of OA and biomineralisation research highlighting how molluscan biomineralisation mechanism might alter, adapt and evolve in the future oceans with high-CO 2 . Biomineralisation related proteins refer to the proteins that are secreted into the EPS, participate in biomineralisation but not deposited in the shell. Other organic components include polysaccharides such as chitin and shell pigments]. MSPs are expressed by mantle, hemocytes as well as other organs such as gills. div.head: Multiple factors have shaped the molluscan evolution over geological time
div.p: To completely understand the adaptation and future of molluscan biomineralisation under rapidly declining carbonate ion saturation levels due to OA, understanding the origin and evolution of the process is vital. The Cambrian explosion (~542 million years ago -Ma) is the origin of several phyla and the diversity of living forms of our planet increased tremendously during this period. The fossil records from the Ediacaran era (~580 Ma) comprises no calcified structures and the first abundant record of calcified animal bodies is from the Cambrian explosion (Runnegar, 1982). The oceans of the Pre-Cambrian era, before the origin of shell forming animals, were supersaturated with CaCO 3 and the possibility of carbonate precipitation was higher (Marin et al., 1996;Knoll et al., 1993). The later Cambrian period was marked with the decrease in the Mg/Ca ratio in the ocean and it was suspected that this might be a reason for the sudden emergence of calcified animals (Tucker, 1992). However, after the classification of oceans of the phanerozoic eon, the geological time scale covering the past 540 million years, into cycles of aragonite and calcitic oceans, it has been suggested that the shell content might have been influenced more by the PCO 2 (vapour pressure of CO 2 ) rather than the Mg/Ca ratio (Sandberg, 1983). There is also another prevailing hypothesis that each type of ocean (either calcitic or aragonitic ocean) might support the growth of animals with the corresponding shell type i.e. calcitic ocean supports calcitic shelled animals and vice-versa (Harper et al., 1997). Global temperature is also considered to be playing a key role in the evolution of biomineralisation process in molluscs (Tucker, 1992). Though, it is still difficult to pinpoint one factor that played a major role as a selective pressure on biomineralisation, environmental factors could be attributed as a major player in shaping the molluscan biomineralisation. As OA directly affects the calcium carbonate saturation levels (ions important for biomineralisation), we focus on increase of pCO 2 level in the oceans due to anthropogenic activities, leading to OA, as a driving force in shaping the molecular evolution of molluscan biomineralisation.

The steadily decreasing carbonate saturation level, due to OA, would directly affect ion transport proteins and MSPs that are involved in biomineralisation (Vidal-Dupiol et al., 2013;Li et al., 2016a). Also, molecular level response to OA happens immediately before observable physiological (shell structure) or ecosystem level changes happen (Somero, 2010;Gavery and Roberts, 2010;Guerrero-Bosagna et al., 2013;Jaenisch and Bird, 2003;Pigllucci, 1996). Hence, it is important to study the role of MSPs in biomineralisation under OA as one of the potential early indicators. The following section elaborates the history and importance of MSPs and ion transporters in biomineralisation (Belcher et al., 1996;Thompson et al., 2000).

div.head: Molluscan shell proteins have been co-opted from various ancient proteins
div.p: The sudden emergence of shelled animals during Cambrian explosion must be the result of the molecular evolution of animals that lived during the pre-Cambrian era. From the knowledge gained in the past two decades, it is evident that MSPs are driving biomineralisation in molluscs (Belcher et al., 1996;Marin and Luquet, 2004). Thus, the origin of these proteins also traces back to the period of Cambrian explosion. A promising theory which explains the origin of MSPs is exaptation theory and the meaning of exaptation is 'not adapted' or 'co-opted' (Gould and Vrba, 1982). The exaptation theory states that the MSPs existed in the system before the origin of shells, however, they were performing other functions than shell formation (Marin et al, 2000). One of the possible other functions is anti-calcification in the Precambrian oceans that were highly supersaturated with CaCO 3 . It had been proposed that this high saturation level might have caused spontaneous crystallisation of CaCO 3 around the soft tissues of Precambrian animals (Knoll et al., 1993). To overcome this spontaneous crystallisation, the animals might have adopted an anti-calcification mechanism, driven by mucus proteins (Marin et al., 1996). The mucus proteins which performed an anti-calcification function before Cambrian explosion, might have exapted the calcification function when the sea water Ca 2þ concentrations increased three-fold during the Cambrian explosion (Brennan et al., 2004). The hypothesis on co-option of ancestral mucin to perform calcification or regulation of calcification was corroborated while studying mucoperlin. Mucoperlin is a mucin like MSP and has ancestry from the mucin like proteins of the Precambrian era (Marin et al, 2000). Several conserved domains of MSPs such as carbonic anhydrase, alkaline phosphatase, tyrosinase, protease inhibitors and peroxidases, have functions that are not related to shell formation as well. This shows how these proteins have been co-opted for shell formation (reviewed by (Kocot et al., 2016)). Another recent study on the transcriptome of several bivalves and gastropods also shows that co-option and de-novo evolution of MSP genes underlies molluscan shell diversity (Aguilera et al., 2017). The MSPs are also known for their repetitive low complexity domains (RLCD), a classic protein structural feature that aids in rapid molecular evolution of these type of genes or proteins in the animal kingdom (McDougall et al., 2013). For example, in Fig. 2, VWFA (Von Willebrand factor type A) domain in BMSP (Blue Mussel Shell Protein) typically contains ~150 amino acids and is repeated several times throughout the protein structure, playing a potential role in protein-protein interaction (Suzuki et al., 2011). Whereas nacrein has alpha carbonic anhydrase 2 as the functional domain. In Fig. 2B, the tandem repeats (TR) or RLCDs of Lustrin A and nacrein obtained by EXSTREAM is shown, where GPA domain is repeated 3.67 times in Lustrin A and NGDNG [N,2]GY is repeated 8.89 times in nacrein. These low complexity domains are unstable i.e. easy to be shuffled, lost and modified (McDougall et al., 2013). This rapidly evolving ability of MSPs might make it easier for the marine calcifiers to adapt rapidly in response to OA (Kocot et al., 2016;McDougall et al., 2013;Jackson et al., 2006). However, the current day observations by laboratory and field experiments show varying yet negative impact of OA on marine calcifiers (Kroeker et al., 2010) which can only be solved by understanding the mechanisms behind biomineralisation in detail under various levels of OA.

div.head: Ion transportersan important molecular machinery in biomineralisation
div.p: As discussed earlier, development of multicellularity and the ability to modify ion activity at sites of diffusion limitation is an important criterion to be considered while understanding the emergence of biomineralisation during the Cambrian (Simkiss, 1989). Molluscan biomineralisation involves the ability to transport and regulate the concentration of calcium and (bi)carbonate ions which is highly controlled by enzymes such as carbonic anhydrase (Miyamoto et al, 1996(Miyamoto et al, , 2005Li et al., 2010). Calcitonin (CT) is a major calcium regulating factor, participating in Ca 2þ homeostasis in vertebrates such as humans (Austin and Heath, 1981). Similarly, CT signalling system of oysters is found to be closely related to CT signalling system of vertebrates playing a role in osmotic homeostasis (Rousseau et al., 2003;Schwartz et al., 2019).

Some examples of ion transporters that are identified as important for biomineralisation are sodium bicarbonate cotransporters, anion exchangers, voltage gated ion channels, calcium transporting ATPases and sodium/calcium exchangers (Li et al., 2016a;Ramesh, 2019). These ion transporters are proteins that aid in the movement of ions across the cell membrane and in a recent study, during the initiation of calcification in blue mussel larvae (Mytilus edulis), ion transporters such as SERCA (sarco/endoplasmic reticulum calcium ATPase proteins), NCX (sodium calcium exchangers) and NBC (sodium bicarbonate cotransporters) were found to be significantly upregulated (Ramesh, 2019). This indicates the crucial role of ion transporters in initiation of biomineralisation in the early life stages of molluscs.

div.head: Major factors affecting biomineralisation in acidifying oceans
div.p: Though the importance of MSPs and ion transporters in biomineralisation is clear, it is unclear which one of the two, play a significant role in shaping the adaptation of molluscan biomineralisation in high CO 2 oceans. The major questions being whether the observed negative effect of OA on marine calcifiers is due to (a) Ω limitation or (b) inability to maintain pH homeostasis or (c) the reduced ability to modify ionic interactions between protein and mineral phases for nucleation and crystal growth. (a) and (b) involves ion transporters whereas (c) is the role of MSPs. Considering these open questions, in this section, we discuss the effects of OA on biomineralisation and the role of MSPs and ion transporters in aiding adaptation in the future high CO 2 oceans under two major categories: 1) Ω limitation 2) Hydrogen ion concentration.

div.head: Ω limitation for biomineralisation
div.p: The net calcification rate of molluscs is the sum of gross calcification rate and the dissolution rate (Cyronak et al., 2015;Rodolfo-Metalpa et al., 2011). Though shell dissolution under OA causes serious damage to calcifiers by reducing the net calcification rate, there is also reduction in the gross calcification rate under OA (Kroeker et al., 2010;

Rodolfo-Metalpa et al., 2011). These OA effects are often linked with reduced CaCO 3 saturation state in the environment. In this section we discuss the prevailing two hypotheses on substrate availability for biomineralisation under OA. 1) Ω limitation: This hypothesis states that undersaturation of [CO 3 À ] under OA, would decrease gross shell calcification rate. This theory considers CO 3 À as a substrate for biomineralisation (Gattuso et al., 1998;Langdon et al., 2000). 2) Ω myth: Different molluscs also employ different biochemical pathways to obtain their shell carbonate, such as from bulk sea water HCO 3 À , metabolic CO 2 and tissue carbonate (reviewed by (Roleda et al., 2012)). According to the Ω myth hypothesis, the term, coined by Cyronak et al., the gross calcification rate might not be affected as the substrate for biomineralisation is HCO 3 À rather than CO 3 À (Cyronak et al., 2015;Roleda et al., 2012). This hypothesis is supported by the fact that there are no carbonate transporters reported in oyster mantle tissues and in calcifiers other than molluscs. However, presence of bicarbonate transporters is reported (Sikes and Wheeler, 1983). Also, the concentration of bicarbonates [HCO 3 À ] is nine times higher than that of carbonates in sea water and acidification increases [HCO 3 À ] further (Cyronak et al., 2015). Thus, Cyronak et al.

null out the hypothesis of reduced substrate availability calling it, "omega myth" (Cyronak et al., 2015). This can also be supported by the observations from several species with increased calcification rates under OA (Ries et al., 2009). Thus, it is believed that the ability of the molluscs to perform normal calcification in acidifying oceans would depend on factors such as ability to maintain pH at the site of calcification (proton flux limitation model) and ability to alter the matrix shell proteins (reviewed by (Ries, 2010)). However, under OA, Saccostrea glomerata, alter their carbon uptake mechanisms indicating that carbon uptake mechanisms can even change with changing environmental conditions in a given species (Fitzer et al., 2019a). Thus, more research on understanding the carbon uptake mechanisms across taxa, under normal and OA conditions, is required before accepting the Ω limitation or the myth theories.

div.head: Proton flux limitation model
div.p: During the process of calcification, there will be release of a H þ ion, when bicarbonate is precipitated as CaCO 3 :
div.formula: HCO 3 À þ Ca 2þ ↔ CaCO 3 þ H þ … (Eq.1)
div.p: The formation of CaCO 3 leads to accumulation of hydrogen ions (Eq. (1) forward reaction) at the site of calcification. This increase of [H þ ] affects the precipitation of CaCO 3 . Thus, hydrogen ions need to be constantly pumped out of the calcification site (passive or active mode) through cellular ion channels or transporters, to maintain the pH and calcification rate (Taylor et al, 2011(Taylor et al, , 2012. Ocean acidification on the other hand, leads to increase of [H þ ] in the seawater. This reduction in electrochemical gradient between the cytosol of the animal and the seawater makes it difficult to maintain the desired pH at the site of calcification. This effect of OA through increase of environmental [H þ ] is called as proton flux limitation model of calcification (Cyronak et al., 2015). However, the applicability of this model across taxa or in molluscs, is uncertain (Waldbusser et al., 2015).

Shell dissolution is the first visible negative impact of OA. This is caused due to the increase in H þ ions in the seawater that has stronger affinity to CO 3 À than Ca 2 þ leading to dissolution of the existing CaCO 3 structures (Eq. (1) reverse reaction). Shells of animals growing under ocean acidification or undersaturation of calcite/aragonite, are observed to be dissolving faster (Bednar� sek et al, 2012a(Bednar� sek et al, , 2012bNienhuis et al., 2010). Increased dissolution rate of the shells of frilled dogwinkle (Nucella lamellose) shows that reduced carbonate saturation levels affect the rate of shell dissolution rather than calcification (Nienhuis et al., 2010). In pteropods, it has been observed that the degree of shell dissolution increases with prolonged exposure of shells to OA conditions and the effect is studied by analysing the microstructure of the shells using Scanning Electron Microscope (SEM) (Bednar� sek et al, 2012a(Bednar� sek et al, , 2012b. In a study, involving a total of 18 different species covering a broad taxonomic range (crustacea, cnidaria, echinoidea, rhodophyta, chlorophyta, gastropoda, Bivalvia and annelida), 10 out of 18 species showed reduced net calcification rate (net calcification rate ¼ the dissolution rate þ gross calcification rate) (Ries et al., 2009). 7 out of the 10 affected species were molluscs. These molluscs, most of them bivalves, that maintain the calcifying fluid pH in the range 7.33-8.53 (Crenshaw, 1972), were found to be more vulnerable to OA than corals that maintain the calcifying fluid pH at 9.3 (Al-Horani et al., 2003). Biogenic CaCO 3 crystals also contain magnesium ions in their lattice. Solubility of different polymorphs of CaCO 3 increases from low magnesium (Mg) calcite (<5 mol% Mg-least soluble) to aragonite to high Mg Calcite (>10 mol% of Mg) (Kroeker et al., 2010;Ries et al., 2009;Morse et al., 2006Morse et al., , 2007. There are also opinions regarding low Mg calcite being preferentially precipitated under OA as it has a lower solubility leading to slower dissolution. In contrast, it is observed that high Mg calcite shell producing animals are more resilient to OA, despite being the highly soluble mineral form (Kroeker et al., 2010). Though dissolution looks like a physical phenomenon, and to be dependent solely on the type of mineral, the mineral interaction with organic content in the shell is an important factor in determining the rate of dissolution. This ionic interaction is heavily dependent on the biological ability of the animal to produce the type of MSPs required for controlling the shell mineral type and the amount of shell organic content which are costly processes (Palmer, 1983(Palmer, , 1992Harper, 2000). The rate of dissolution depends on crystal size, organic content of the shell and the type of the periostracum (outermost organic shell layer) (Harper, 2000). The molluscan periostracum is also a neglected but important constraint in molluscan evolution (Harper, 1997). The response of animals in changing the organic content and the periostracum of the shell under OA is an important parameter for understanding the future of calcifiers (Rodolfo-Metalpa et al., 2011).

The molecular response of molluscan biomineralisation machinery to these two factors (reduced substrate availability and increased [H þ ]) that affect biomineralisation under OA remains unclear. OA scientists have attempted to answer these questions by using short term lab-based experiments and a combination of wide range of techniques ranging from simple shell length measurements to sophisticated gene expression analysis [reviewed by (Fitzer et al., 2019b)]. In the following section, we give insights into some of the known answers while hypothesising the unknown about the fate of biomineralisation process under OA.

div.head: Acclimation and adaptation of biomineralisation under acidifying oceans
div.p: The term acclimation is generally used for short term laboratory level responses by an organism within a single generation, whereas the term adaptation refers to millions of years in time scale, the changes that happen in genetic level over generations (Raven and Geider, 2003;Morgan-Kiss et al., 2006). In this section, we use the existing knowledge on biomineralisation under OA based on laboratory level short term (hours to days and months) acclimation experiments and the long evolutionary history of biomineralisation, to explain the adaptation potential of molluscs to the future acidifying oceans. This section on the adaptative molecular responses of molluscan biomineralisation machinery is divided into three major sections: 1) Energy budgeting driven differential gene expression 2) Rapid evolution of MSPs and co-option 3) Unexplored qualitative changes of MSPs.

Here, when the Ω drops, k must be increased by adding energy to maintain the constant calcification rate. A system with slow calcification rate, such as brooding oysters would require less energy for compensation under OA, compared to a system with high calcification rate, such as non-brooding oysters (Waldbusser et al., 2016). Similarly, early larval stages of oysters have little ability to separate calcifying fluid from the sea water, together with high calcification rate comparing the juvenile and adult life stages. As a result, early larval stages require more energy for compensation under OA, compared to adult stages (Waldbusser et al., 2013). However, biomineralisation is not a mere chemical precipitation process, it involves proteins and ion transporters. Thus, under OA, it would require ion transporters to pump more ions into the biomineralisation site and/or differential expression of ion transporters and molluscan shell proteins to maintain the same reaction rate (r), under decreasing Ω. Differential gene expression is an important indicator of adaptation against stressors in living systems across various taxa (Harding et al., 2017;Slotte et al., 2007;Kenkel and Matz, 2017). However, increased gene or protein expression by more than two factor is proved to have significant energetic costs causing growth reduction (Wagner, 2005). Changes in gene expression affects energy budgeting of a cell (Wagner, 2007). This shows that the adaptation for OA observed through differential gene expression might not be an evolutionarily neutral process, meaning, differential gene expression is a costly process. In addition, biomineralisation itself is a metabolically expensive process, especially the synthesis of organic components of the shell is energy demanding (Palmer, 1992) but, essential for maintaining the shell integrity and repair (Falini et al., 1996). For example, in blue mussels (Mytilus edulis), it has been shown that the shift in energy allocation might be the potential mechanism behind the reduced shell growth under OA (Thomsen et al., 2013). Three independent studies on blue mussels, Mytilus edulis, have reached a similar conclusion that shell integrity depends on food availability or energy limitation, rather than OA (Thomsen et al., 2013;Melzner et al., 2011;Mackenzie et al., 2014). In gastropods, such as Zeacumantus subcarinatus, OA reduces shell growth and shell tensile strength. There was also interactive effect between parasitic infection and OA, where infected snails showed increased shell growth and dissolution with decreased strength comparing uninfected snails (MacLeod and Poulin, 2015). In Concholepas concholepas (rock snails), no change in shell growth was found under OA, however other behaviour changes such as ability to self-right was affected (Manríquez et al., 2013). Prolonged exposure to natural CO 2 vents was also found to be severely affecting the shells of gastropods, Phorcus sauciatus, due to greater shell dissolution (Viotti et al., 2019). A recent study on two inter-tidal gastropods, Tegula funebralis and Nucella ostrina, under OA, T. funebralis showed 83% reduction in shell growth and 50% reduction in shell strength whereas N. ostrina's shell growth was unaffected with only 10% reduction in the shell strength (Barclay et al., 2019). Inter-tidal zone usually experiences greater environmental fluctuations and hence inter-tidal gastropod species are found to be better adaptive to OA than sub-tidal species (Leung et al., 2017). These studies also show that the response exhibited by molluscs to OA, though generally found to be negative, is species specific and vary depending on the range of environmental fluctuations these species have been previously exposed to.

Studies on other calcifiers such as corals have also shown that food availability would help in tackling the harmful effects of OA (Edmunds, 2011;Crook et al., 2013;Drenkard et al., 2013;Towle et al., 2015). Certain organisms also show reduced feeding rates even under high food availability for which the reason could be insensitivity to food or metabolic depression. Energy availability has a strong correlation with differential gene expression i.e. if there is a need to change gene expression under stressors, any living system would require more energy than usual. In a recent study on gastropod Crepidula fornicate, reduced nutrition (energy) acts as a co-stressor with OA affecting larval competence for metamorphosis (Bogan et al., 2019). This shows energy availability as an important parameter for acclimation or adaptation. Thus, studying the interplay of energy availability and differential gene expression is an essential first step towards understanding adaptation of molluscan biomineralisation to OA.

To summarise, three simplified cases of energy budgeting are hypothesised in Fig. 3, where Case A denotes the normal condition without any stressor, where energy budgeting for housekeeping, immune response, reproduction and biomineralisation is optimum; Case B denotes the stressed condition where molluscs spend less energy over the production of shell proteins diverting the energy for other housekeeping functions. This affects the strength of the shells and energy reserve and Case C denotes the stressed condition where energy is spent on maintaining the optimum biomineralisation compensating the requirement for ion transport due to lower Ω and higher dissolution rates. Food supply is known to have an impact on animal's response to stressors (Hüning et al., 2013;Melzner et al, 2011Melzner et al, , 2013. With enough energy, molluscs might be able to tackle the negative effects of OA and other stressors (Thomsen et al., 2013). These three cases can be further expanded to distinguish the energy budgeting among the two major categories of biomineralisation related genesion transporters and MSPs which is further explained in the following subsection.

div.head: Strategic energy regulation of ion transporters and MSPs under OA
div.p: Energy budgeting for biomineralisation includes the energy spent on MSPs and ion transporters that supply raw materials (ions) such as calcium and bicarbonate required for biomineralisation. The energy allotted for these two processes depend on the environmental conditions such as OA (Ω and the pH of the ocean). To understand the splitting of the energy between these two processes we have reviewed the response of molluscs under OA, classifying either the response is from MSPs or from ion transporters under OA. MSPs take part in biomineralisation by controlling the nucleation, crystal growth and gets incorporated into the shells to form a structural framework together with polysaccharides such as Chitin (Yan et al., 2007;Politi et al., 2007;Lao et al., 2007;Ehrlich, 2010). In blue mussels, Mytilus edulis, grown under OA, there was decreased expression of chitinase, an enzyme which degrades chitin. Reducing the degradation of chitin would eventually lead to retention of chitin, which is a raw material for biomineralisation. As chitin forms the organic framework of the shell and the reduction of chitin degradation might be an energy saving strategy during high chitin demand. This adjustment in chitin formation/degradation cycle, while not changing the chitin synthase expression is an example of strategic regulation of gene expression and energy usage (Hüning et al., 2013). Whereas, the expression of tyrosinase, an MSP found in higher amounts in the periostracum, the outer most organic layer covering the shell, was massively upregulated 220-fold (Hüning et al., 2013). This shows that molluscs show adaptive response by balancing the energy usage by reducing the production of chitinase and increasing the production of tyrosinase which makes the periostracum (surface layer) stronger to circumvent the erosion or dissolution of the shell. This study found no differential expression of certain chosen MSPs such as SILK, NACR, PLUC, CSP, SPARC, PWAP and MUC (Hüning et al., 2013). In another study, when blue mussels, Mytilus edulis, were exposed to OA, there was decrease in carbonic anhydrase activity, observed with a change in shell microstructure (Fitzer et al., 2014a). Larval oyster (Crassostrea gigas) grown under reduced aragonite saturation conditions showed delayed shell development (De Wit et al., 2018). Comparative gene expression (transcriptomic) analysis between the larvae grown under ambient conditions and reduced aragonite saturation conditions showed differences in expression of genes related to metabolism, ion transport, shell matrix proteins and protease inhibitors (De Wit et al., 2018). Some of the shell proteins that were differentially expressed includes chitin binding protein, c type lectin, fibrinogen, carbonic anhydrase or nacrein like protein and galactose binding protein (De Wit et al., 2018). The study also reports the delay in lipid breakdown which shows there is link between the energy budgeting and delayed expression of shell proteins.

However, there are few studies in molluscs and other calcifiers to date, that used the comparative transcriptome approach under OA with a specific focus over biomineralisation (Vidal-Dupiol et al., 2013;Li et al., 2016a;Ramesh, 2019;De Wit et al., 2018;Liu et al., 2012;Goncalves et al., 2017;Koh et al., 2015;Maas et al., 2015;Johnson and Hofmann, 2017;Moya et al., 2012;Evans et al., 2013;Griffiths et al., 2019;Kenkel et al., 2018;Yuan et al., 2019;Rokitta et al., 2012;O'Donnell et al., 2010;De Wit and Palumbi, 2013). Among them, only eight are on molluscs and a recent blue mussel (Mytilus edulis) larval study uses limited substrate availability C T to identify genes involved in biomineralisation (Ramesh, 2019). Under substrate limitation conditions, the larvae strongly upregulates ion transporters that are important for biomineralisation (Ramesh, 2019). Locally adapted red abalone for OA conditions are found to have SNPs in both MSPs and energy metabolism related genes (De Wit and Palumbi, 2013). Pearl oysters, Pinctada fucata, respond to OA by upregulating ion transporters and undergoing metabolic depression (Li et al, 2016a(Li et al, , 2016b. In pteropods, after 10 h of OA exposure, MSPs such as c-type lectin and collagen were upregulated (Maas et al., 2015). In another short-term OA experiment of 96 h, arctic pteropod showed downregulation of 9 out of 14 MSPs differentially expressed (Koh et al., 2015). Transcriptomic analysis of an Antarctic pteropod revealed upregulation of genes related to shell formation and calcium binding under OA (Johnson and Hofmann, 2017). In contrast, there are also studies, particularly in eastern oysters, Crassostrea virginica, in which the expression of MSPs or ion transporters are not affected under OA (Matoo et al., 2013;Tomanek et al., 2011;Dickinson et al., 2012) which shows that molluscs show differential adaptative response to OA (Kroeker et al., 2010). To summarise, expression of several MSPs is compromised under OA, certain MSPs are strategically upregulated to counterbalance the negative effect due to downregulation (Hüning et al., 2013;Koh et al., 2015). Also, from these studies, we can observe that under OA many ion transporters are upregulated to maintain the ion supply required for biomineralisation and to maintain pH homeostasis indicating the importance of ion transporter machinery in the process of adapting to OA. Thus, molluscs employ a strategic regulation of gene expression under OA, by upregulating the most important ion transporters and MSPs that are needed to immediately counteract the OA stress; the energy required for this upregulation is obtained by downregulating the least important ion transporters or MSPs or by metabolic depression. For example, as explained above, downregulation of chitinase and upregulation of tyrosinase (Hüning et al., 2013); downregulation of 9 MSPs and upregulation of 5 MSPs (Koh et al., 2015); upregulation of ion transporters while undergoing metabolic depression (Li et al, 2016a(Li et al, , 2016b. This strategic regulation would potentially allow molluscs to continue building their shells in high CO 2 oceans while compromising the shell quality in terms of shell crystallography and shell microstructure (Fitzer et al, 2014a(Fitzer et al, , 2014b(Fitzer et al, , 2016(Fitzer et al, , 2019aMeng et al., 2018). Differential gene expression can be caused either by a cis-regulatory mutation or epigenetic modification. These changes when passed on to the next generation will drive the adaptation and evolution of molluscs (Drenkard et al., 2013;Towle et al., 2015). Another important feature of MSPs that aid in their rapid evolution is their Repetitive Low Complexity Domains (RLCDs). RLCDs and their role in evolution of MSPs is discussed in the next section.

div.head: Rapid evolution of MSPs and co-option under OA
div.p: Repetitive Low Complexity Domains (RLCDs) are characteristic feature of MSPs (Fig. 2) which helps them to evolve rapidly and have proclivity to expand, contract and rearrange in the genome (Jackson et al., 2009). RLCD containing MSPs are also from very diverse origin, with some of them being ancient and some being novel (Aguilera et al., 2017). The genes coding MSPs are also at the periphery of the biomineralisation gene regulatory network (GRNs) which enables them to leave or enter the network easily (Aguilera et al., 2017) (Fig. 4). GRNs refer to the controlling machinery behind gene and protein expression of a cell including transcription regulatory network (TRN) and protein network (Fig. 4). The expression is determined by interaction between molecular regulators such as DNA, RNA and proteins. These regulatory networks are important for determining the morphology of the shell (Jackson and Degnan, 2016) and hence adaptation to stressors and evolution. By controlling the final outputs of shell fabrication and being at the physical periphery of the mantle cells, MSPs are at the periphery of this gene regulatory network (Aguilera et al., 2017). The periphery of GRNs are controlled by few transcription factors (Davidson, 2010) which only requires few modifications to the cis-regulatory region of genes expressing MSPs to enter or leave the GRN at higher rates (Aguilera et al., 2017). These modifications can be genetic or epigenetic in nature (Gavery and Roberts, 2010;Putnam et al., 2016). For example: two closely related species of pearl oysters (Pinctada species) showed differential expression of orthologous tyrosinase genes showing that the regulation of the expression had changed in these two species as they diverged (Aguilera et al., 2014(Aguilera et al., , 2017. Under OA (Fig. 4), the changes in the water chemistry will be detected first by the transmembrane proteins including the ion transporters followed by changes in the gene and protein expression under the control of the GRN. Biomineralisation related genes being at the periphery of the network, under OA, molluscs might recruit proteins currently performing other functions to add strength to their shells and differentially regulate the existing MSPs. There can also be loss of proteins currently performing biomineralisation. These expected changes in GRNs and RLCDs of biomineralisation under OA has not been studied extensively yet and remains highly unknown. Some of the protein domains that are repeatedly co-opted into mantle secretomes perform functions such as hydrolysis, protein phosphorylation, oxidation-reduction processes, extracellular interactions, immunity, and calcium & carbohydrate metabolism (Aguilera et al., 2017). Some of these functions such as oxidation-reduction processes, calcium and carbohydrate metabolism are also affected under OA (Hüning et al., 2013;Ricevuto et al., 2016;Matozzo et al., 2013;Freitas et al., 2017) which shows that co-option might already be happening in the rapidly acidifying oceans.

div.head: Unexplored qualitative changes to MSPs under OA
div.p: Shell microstructure is controlled by MSPs (Marie et al., 2012b;Falini et al., 1996;Belcher et al., 1996). OA is found to pose threats to the control of biomineralisation by altering the shell crystal orientation which is often linked to reduced activity of carbonic anhydrase (Fitzer et al, 2014a(Fitzer et al, , 2014b. The reduction in the activity of carbonic anhydrase can be accounted to either reduced expression or changes in the quality of the protein. In several cases, there is no change observed in the gene or protein expression of the MSPs (Hüning et al., 2013;Dineshram et al, 2012Dineshram et al, , 2016 and to our knowledge, there is no study which focuses over the Post Translational Modifications (PTMs) of MSPs under OA. MSPs in general are heavily glycosylated or phosphorylated through post translational modifications (Sarashina and Endo, 2001;Samata et al., 2008). Changes in the PTMs of a protein is proven to modulate the activity of proteins (Mann and Jensen, 2003). The importance of PTMs in shell diversity has also been briefly mentioned while discussing the evolution of MSPs (Jackson et al., 2006). The reduced activity of carbonic anhydrase found during reduced calcium carbonate saturation can be also accounted to deficiency in PTMs. This qualitative perspective on MSPs is Fig. 4. MSPs and ion transporters at the periphery of Gene Regulatory Network in mantle epithelium: From right to left, nucleus is where the regulation of transcription occurs, and cytosol is where translation and transport of MSPs are regulated. After transcription, translation and transport of MSPs and ion transporters to the Extra Pallial Space (EPS) and cell membrane respectively, they function at the physical periphery of the mantle epithelial cell. Being at the physical periphery of the cell and hence at the periphery of the gene regulatory network of mantle epithelium, MSPs and ion transporters evolve rapidly with changes in the environmental conditions and stressors. This also helps in co-option and loss of genes from biomineralisation network (Aguilera et al., 2017) (figure inspired from gene regulatory network of B-cell lymphoma (de Matos Simoes et al., 2012)).
often neglected while studying the effects of OA.

As explained in Fig. 5, oxidative stress caused by various stressors (Matoo et al., 2013;Ricevuto et al., 2016;Matozzo et al., 2013) often lead to activation of kinases (Aikawa et al., 1997;Gopalakrishna and Jaken, 2000;Huot et al., 1997). This change in kinase levels might alter the level of phosphorylation of MSPs. As it is discovered recently that MSPs exert specific ionic interaction pattern for controlling biomineralisation, the changes in phosphorylation can alter the charge of these proteins and thus their function (Pendola and Evans, 2018). As mentioned earlier, protein domains with the phosphorylation function are also highly co-opted in for biomineralisation (Aguilera et al., 2017) which further supports this hypothesis. The amount of chitin, a polysaccharide, which is found together with MSPs, is also found to be altered under stressors (Hüning et al., 2013). Chitin is also found to have anti-oxidative effect (Ngo et al., 2008), indicating the increased expression of chitin synthesis related genes might be favourable in reducing oxidative stress. This response for tackling oxidative stress might affect the glycosylation status of MSPs and thus their function. Based on these observations, we propose that the post translation status of MSPs might be modified due to the influence of OA and studying the qualitative aspect is equally important in understanding the effects of OA on MSPs. Qualitative studies would also lead to better understanding of the type of interactions involved between MSPs and other molecules involved in biomineralisation.

div.head: Concluding remarks
div.p: From the existing knowledge, molecular evolution of molluscan biomineralisation occurs through differential expression, co-option and loss of biomineralisation related genes and proteins. Differential gene expression is easily facilitated by the simple cis-gene regulatory network of biomineralisation related genes. However, the mechanisms behind this gene regulation is still unclear under OA. It might be through natural genetic modifications such as Single Nucleotide Polymorphisms (or) through the classic feature of MSPs -RLCDs (or) epigenetic modifications such as DNA methylation, histone modifications etc. There is focus over differential expression of MSPs, however it should be considered together with the energetic costs involved. Thus, to conclude, we suggest four important future research directions for molecular adaptation of molluscan biomineralisation in high-CO 2 oceans: 1) Including an energy budgeting factor while understanding differential expression of MSPs and ion transporters under OA. 2) Unraveling the genetic or epigenetic changes in GRNs and RLCDs of molluscan biomineralisation under stressors to help solving a bigger picture about future evolution of molluscs, 3) Understanding Post Translational Modifications of MSPs with and without stressors, and 4) Understanding carbon uptake mechanisms across taxa with and without OA to clarify the OA theories on Ω.
